hyp_text: Louis XVI, 16 August 1754 – 21 January 1793, was a Bourbon monarch who ruled as King of France and Navarre until 1791, and then as King of the French from 1791 to 1792, before his deposition and execution during the French Revolution. By the standards of the time, Louis XVI was a enlightened absolute monarch. He attempted to reform the French government in accordance with the principles of the Enlightenment, and to address the financial situation of France’s debt-laden economy. His attempts resulted in a combined constitutional monarchy and absolutist centralised autocracy. After he was forced to abdicate his throne in September 1791, he was tried by the National Convention, found guilty of high treason, and executed by guillotine on 21 January 1793. The French Revolution, which began in 1789, ended the French monarchy. In a context of volatile and unfulfilled promises of change, the king was sentenced to death for high treason and other alleged crimes. He was executed by guillotine on 21 January 1793, as a rebel against the Republic and a danger to its security. He was the last king to die in France.
